discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The key detail is that the unauthorized person was physically present in a secure facility, as captured on video. Installing a rogue access point requires physical access to connect the device to the network or place it within range. Options A, B, and C are either attack types or external activities that don’t address the physical entry. Tailgating (D) directly explains how the person bypassed physical security to get inside and install the device. Without such access, the installation couldn’t have occurred, regardless of the subsequent attack method (

D. Tailgating

questions.question_text: A company discovers on video surveillance recordings that an unauthorized person installed a rogue access point in its secure facility. Which of the following allowed the unauthorized person to do this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
DCI isn’t a protocol. GRE and VXLAN are tunneling/overlay protocols but lack native encryption, requiring additional security layers (IPSec) to be secure.

IPSec directly addresses security with encryption and authentication, making it a standard choice for site-to-site VPNs over the internet. It can also encapsulate other protocols if needed, but as a standalone solution, it meets the requirement for secure communication.

 D. IPSec

questions.question_text: A secure communication link needs to be configured between data centers via the internet. The data centers are located in different regions. Which of the following is the best protocol for the network administrator to use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Jump box

The jump box is a standard, effective solution for securing access to management interfaces, often used in enterprise environments to enforce policies like multi-factor authentication, logging, and network segmentation.

A console server (B) is more about access than security layering.

An API interface (C) facilitates interaction, not protection.

In-band management (D) is the opposite of adding security, as it integrates management with regular network traffic.

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be implemented to add an additional layer of security between a corporate network and network management interfaces?

choices.D: An incorrect cable type was installed.
choices.A: The PoE power budget was exceeded.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The most likely reason is C, a port security violation. Replacing the NIC changes the MAC address, and if the switch was locked to the old MAC, it would block the new one, causing users to lose access. This aligns with common network administration experiences post-upgrade. B is a close contender if cabling was manually altered, but port security is a more frequent culprit in such scenarios.

A (PoE) is unlikely because servers don’t typically use PoE, and a NIC upgrade wouldn’t affect a power budget.

B (TX/RX transposed) could occur if cabling was disturbed or a mismatched setup was introduced, but Auto-MDI/MDIX reduces this likelihood in modern setups.

D (Incorrect cable) is possible but less probable with modern auto-correcting hardware.

questions.question_text: A network administrator performed upgrades on a server and installed a new NIC to improve performance. Following the upgrades, users are unable to reach the server. Which of the following is the most likely reason?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Only unsecure port is B

Selected Answer: B
B is the only unsecured option (HTTP)

Port 80 is the unsecure port of HTTPS hence port 80 is HTTP. This port out of all the other ports are unsecure. 
22- ssh secure
443- https secure
587- SMTPS Secure version of STMP

Selected Answer: B
Port 80 is an insecure hypertext transfer protocol
